items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob Nuñez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Dan Moser, Associate Superintendnet of Instructiona and Human RelationsSUBJECT:9.00 Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 7:30 p.m. Regarding the Approval of the General Waiver Request CAHSEE Apportionment - DESCRIPTION: The California State Board of Education requires districts to hold a public hearing so that persons may comment on the fact that a school applied for a general waiver. The purpose of this hearing is to allow public comment on Appling for a General Waiver for CAHSEE apportionment funding for San Jose Conservation Corp Charter School. This waiver would allow them to receive the money they would have been entitled to receive had they filed their 2006-07 apportionment data with the CDE.
items.item_text: Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 7:30 p.m. regarding the Approval of the General Waiver Request – CAHSEE Apportionment - Dan Moser, Associate Superintendent of Instruction and Human Relations

This waiver was previously submitted with the Superintendent’s signature but the CDE has changed its policy to require school Board approval. FISCAL IMPACT:N/AFUNDING SOURCE:N/ARECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve this waiver request.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Dan Moser, Associate Superintendnet of Instruction and Human RelationsSUBJECT:Accept the Amended Valenzuela/CAHSEE Williams Quarterly ReportBACKGROUNDThe Board of Trustees revised BP 1312 (Uniform Complaint Procedures) through the adoption of a BP 1312.1(a) Supplement and accompanying regulations.  This “supplement” section to BP 1312 incorporates the recent requirements of EC 35186 (Williams: SB550 and AB2727), which requires a different complaint form and timeline.  Additionally, it is required that staff bring to the Board of Trustees a quarterly report of Williams complaints filed and their current disposition.  The attached report indicates the number of complaints filed from July 1, 2008 through September 30, 2008.    FISCAL IMPACT:Unknown at this time.FUNDING SOURCE:Senate Bill 6 (Williams)State Instructional Materials AllocationDistrict Instructional Materials BudgetOther Categorical funds as AppropriateRECOMMENDATION:The administration recommends that the Governing Board accept the amended third Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint report for the period covering July 1, 2008 through September 30, 2008, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTRESOLUTION #2008/2009-15CALIFORNIA BUDGET CRISISWHEREAS, California’s more than six million students deserve high-quality schools with well-trained educators, small class sizes, quality instructional materials, up-to-date textbooks and dynamic parental support; andWHEREAS, schools have already been cut $2.8 billion 2008-2009, resulting in massive and devastating cuts to K-12 students and schools; andWHEREAS, these cuts have meant a reduction of essential programs and services to students that are integral to their success, including the elimination of supplemental instruction programs, GATE and Advanced Placement classes, closing school libraries, reducing counseling services and other support services and increasing class size; andWHEREAS, this has resulted in teacher layoffs statewide and a further erosion of the support system for students provided by thousands of classified and paraprofessional staff that were previously laid off; and WHEREAS, the East Side Union High School District has suffered more than $100 million underfunding over the last several years, damaging local efforts in every aspect of education, including up-to-date textbooks, ongoing teacher training and small class sizes; andWHEREAS, further budget reductions in a public education funding model that has been greatly flawed since 1978 are fundamentally inconsistent with the State’s goal of improving student achievement at a time when our students are making progress toward meeting rigorous State and Federal education standards; andWHEREAS, the cuts already made to schools will have long-term, lasting effects well beyond 2008-2009, taking years to recover from such setbacks, and further cuts to education will have catastrophic consequences for our schools, students and this State's future; andWHEREAS, additional education cuts will result in more layoffs, reduction of employee hours and reduced district/county office purchases of goods and services, all of which are bad for businesses and the economy; andWHEREAS, cuts alone won’t close the massive deficit that the State is facing and increasing revenues must be a priority for the Legislature and the Governor; andWHEREAS, the State’s budget problem was not created by our students and fixing the problem should not come at the expense of their educational progress and success; thereforeBE IT RESOLVED that the East Side Union High School District demands immediate action by the Legislature and Governor that recognizes the cuts schools have already made and solves the budget crisis with a balanced approach that includes revenue increases.PASSED AND ADOPTED this 15th day of January 2009 by the Governing Board of the East Side Union High School District at its regular meeting held at 830 N. Capitol Avenue, San Jose, State of California.	AYES: ________	NOES: ________	ABSENT: ______	ABSTAIN: _____I certify the foregoing resolution was duly introduced, passed, and adopted by the ESUHSD Board of Education at a meeting held on January 15, 2009._________________________ClerkESUHSD Board of Education
items.item_text: Adopt Resolution #2008/2009-15 California Budget Crisis - Bob Nunez, Superintendent
items.item_text_raw: 9.11 Adopt Resolution #2008/2009-15 California Budget Crisis - Bob Nunez, Superintendent

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesSUBJECT:Adopt Resolution 2008/2009-16 Special Education Mandate Cost SettlementApproval of Behavioral Intervention Plans (Hughes Bill) Mandated Cost Claim Settlement and Agreement to Waive Future ClaimsIn response to legislation (AB 2586, the Hughes Bill), the State Board of Eduation in 1993 adopted regulations requiring Local Education Agencies (LEAs) to develop Behavioral Intervention Plans (BIPs) for special education students who exhibit serious behavioral problems.  the regulations imposed detailed and costly requirements that exceed federal law.  This claim has been tied up in the mandate reimbursement process and in the courts for over 14 years.This resolution authorizes a settlement and agreeemnt that starting in 2009-10, SELPA's funding rate will increase by about $10.92 per P-2 ADA with the amount increasing by the cost of living adjustment and ADA growth in subsequent years.  In addition, in settlement of the BIP costs going back to 1993-94, the District will receive annual installments over six years starting in 2011-12 and ending in 2016-17.  The District will receive approximately $2,130,000 in discretionary funding for retroactive reimbursment from 2011/12 with the amount of $355,000 for six years.  All payments will be made into school districts' general funds based on 2007-08 P2 ADA.
items.item_text: Adopt Resolution 2008/2009-16 Special Education Mandate Cost Settlement - Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business Services
items.item_text_raw: 9.12 Adopt Resolution 2008/2009-16 Special Education Mandate Cost Settlement - Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business Services

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesSUBJECT:Receive Summary of General Obligation Bond SaleIn March 2002, District voters passed a $298 million General Obligation Bond program with 69.9% of voters approving the measure.  In November 2008, the District issued its final issuance on General Obligation Bonds, 2002 Election, Series H in the amount of $18,000,000.  State law requires a summary that details the interest rates and costs of issuance of the bonds be placed on a Board agenda.
